articles.simplifiedContent:
Title: Goldman Sachs Uses New AI Technology to Help Their Business

Goldman Sachs, a big bank, is using a new kind of artificial intelligence (AI) from a company called Anthropic. This AI, known as the Claude model, is being used to make their work easier and faster, especially when dealing with money and helping new clients get started.

Many large banks are starting to use AI to do their jobs better. For Goldman Sachs, this means using AI to handle things like counting money and setting up accounts for new customers. The goal is to make everything more efficient, which means getting things done more quickly and with fewer mistakes.

This change is part of a larger trend where banks are trying to use new technology to improve how they work. By using AI, they hope to save time and money, and also give better service to their customers.

In simple terms, AI is helping Goldman Sachs do their work more smoothly, which is good for the bank and its customers.

articles.title: Insurance giant AIG deploys agentic AI with orchestration layer
articles.summary: American International Group (AIG) has reported faster than expected gains from its use of generative AI, with implications for underwriting capacity, operating cost, and portfolio integration. The company’s recent disclosures at an Investor Day merit attention from AI decision-makers as they contai...
articles.simplifiedContent:
**Title: AIG Uses New AI Technology to Improve Its Services**

AIG, a big insurance company, has started using a new kind of computer technology called AI (Artificial Intelligence) to help improve its services. This technology is making things faster and cheaper for the company, which is good news for both the business and its customers.

AI is like a super-smart computer that can learn and make decisions. AIG is using this to help with things like deciding who gets insurance and managing their different services. Because of this technology, AIG can work more efficiently, saving time and money.

At a recent event, AIG shared that their AI is working even better than they expected. This is important because it shows how AI can really help big companies improve what they do. For customers, this might mean better service and possibly even lower costs in the future.

Overall, AIG's use of AI is a big step forward in how insurance companies can use technology to provide better services to people.

articles.title: Alibaba Qwen is challenging proprietary AI model economics
articles.summary: The release of Alibaba’s latest Qwen model challenges proprietary AI model economics with comparable performance on commodity hardware. While US-based labs have historically held the performance advantage, open-source alternatives like the Qwen 3.5 series are closing the gap with frontier models. Th...
articles.simplifiedContent:
Title: Alibaba's New AI Model is Shaking Up the Tech World

Alibaba, a big technology company from China, has released a new AI model called Qwen. This model is causing a stir because it works just as well as some of the most advanced AI models, but it doesn't need super expensive computers to run.

In the past, the best-performing AI models were mostly made by American companies and needed very powerful and costly machines. But now, Alibaba's Qwen is showing that you can get similar results without spending a fortune on fancy equipment. This is a big deal because it means more people and companies can use advanced AI without breaking the bank.

Qwen is part of a growing trend of open-source AI models. "Open-source" means that the technology is available for anyone to use and improve. This openness is helping to level the playing field, allowing more people around the world to develop and use AI technology.

For everyday people, this could lead to more affordable and accessible AI tools in the future, making advanced technology a part of everyday life for more people.

articles.title: SS&C Blue Prism: On the journey from RPA to agentic automation
articles.summary: For organizations who are still wedded to the rules and structures of robotic process automation (RPA), then considering agentic AI as the next step for automation may be faintly terrifying. SS&C Blue Prism, however, is here to help, taking customers on the journey from RPA to agentic automation at ...
articles.simplifiedContent:
**Title: How SS&C Blue Prism is Making Work Easier with New Automation Tools**

If you work in a place that uses computers to do lots of repetitive tasks, you might have heard of something called RPA, which stands for Robotic Process Automation. It's a way to get computers to do simple, repetitive jobs for us, like entering data or sending emails. But there's something new and exciting coming up called "agentic automation."

SS&C Blue Prism is a company that helps businesses use these automation tools to make work easier. They're now helping companies move from using simple automation (RPA) to this new kind of smarter automation. Imagine having a computer program that not only does simple tasks but also makes decisions and learns over time. That's what agentic automation is all about.

For everyday people, this means that the boring parts of your job can be done by computers, leaving you more time to focus on interesting and creative work. SS&C Blue Prism is guiding businesses to make this change smoothly, so employees can benefit from smarter technology without feeling overwhelmed. It's like having a super helpful assistant who gets better at the job the more they do it!

articles.title: Password managers' promise that they can't see your vaults isn't always true
articles.summary: Contrary to what password managers say, a server compromise can mean game over....
articles.simplifiedContent:
**Title: Are Your Passwords Really Safe? What You Need to Know**

Did you know that the apps you use to keep track of your passwords might not be as secure as you think? Many people use password managers (apps that store all your passwords in one place) because they promise to keep your information safe and private. They say that not even they can see what's inside your "vault" (the secure place where your passwords are stored).

But here's the catch: if a hacker breaks into the company's servers (the computers where the company stores data), they might be able to see your passwords. This is like someone finding the key to your safe and looking inside.

So, what does this mean for you? It's a reminder to be careful with how you store your passwords. Even though password managers are generally safer than writing passwords down or using the same one everywhere, they’re not perfect.

To stay extra safe, make sure you use strong, unique passwords for each account and turn on two-factor authentication (a second step to verify it's really you) whenever possible. This way, even if someone does get your password, they can’t easily access your accounts.

articles.title: Banking AI in multiple business functions at NatWest
articles.summary: NatWest Group has expanded the use of artificial intelligence in several areas of its operations, citing customer service, document management in its wealth management division, and software development. According to a blog post by its chief information officer, Scott Marcar, 2025 was the first year...
articles.simplifiedContent:
**Title: How NatWest is Using AI to Help Customers**

NatWest, a big bank, is using artificial intelligence (AI) to make things better for their customers and their own work. AI is like a super-smart computer program that can help with lots of tasks.

At NatWest, AI is helping in a few important areas:

1. **Customer Service**: AI is making it easier and faster for customers to get help. This means when you have a question or problem, AI can help answer it quickly.

2. **Managing Documents**: In the part of the bank that helps people with their investments and savings (wealth management), AI is organizing papers and information. This makes it easier for the bank to keep track of everything and help customers with their money.

3. **Creating Software**: AI is also helping the bank's tech team build new programs and tools that can make banking better for everyone.

Scott Marcar, a leader at NatWest, shared these updates. The bank started using AI in these ways back in 2025. By using AI, NatWest hopes to make banking smoother and more efficient for everyone.

articles.title: Debenhams pilots agentic AI commerce via PayPal integration
articles.summary: Debenhams is piloting agentic AI commerce via PayPal integration to reduce mobile friction and help solve a familiar problem for retailers. articles.simplifiedContent:
**Title: Debenhams Tries New AI Shopping Tech with PayPal**

Debenhams, a well-known store, is trying out a new way of shopping online to make things easier for customers. They're using something called "agentic AI," which is just a fancy way of saying smart technology that helps you shop. This is being tested with PayPal, a popular way to pay online.

The big problem they're tackling is when people start to buy something on their phones but stop before finishing. This happens a lot, and stores lose money because of it. Debenhams wants to fix this issue by making it simpler and faster to check out, or finish buying, on their mobile site.

By using this new smart tech, Debenhams hopes more people will complete their purchases without getting frustrated and leaving the site. If this works, it could mean more sales for the store and a smoother shopping experience for customers. So, next time you shop online at Debenhams, you might notice it's easier to buy what you want!

articles.title: URBN tests agentic AI to automate retail reporting
articles.summary: Retail decisions often depend on weekly performance reports, but compiling those reports can take hours of manual work. Urban Outfitters Inc. (URBN) is testing a new approach by using agentic AI systems to generate those reports automatically, changing routine analysis from staff to software. The re...
articles.simplifiedContent:
Title: How Urban Outfitters is Making Retail Reports Easier with AI

Urban Outfitters, a popular clothing store, is trying out a new way to make work easier. Usually, their staff spends hours putting together weekly reports to see how well the store is doing. These reports help them decide what clothes to order and what sales to run. 

But now, they’re using something called agentic AI, which is just a smart computer program that can do this work automatically. This means the computer can gather and organize all the important information without anyone having to do it by hand. 

For the people who work at Urban Outfitters, this means they can spend less time on boring paperwork and more time on fun and creative tasks, like coming up with new ideas for the store. 

For shoppers, it could mean better choices and more exciting sales because the staff has more time to focus on what customers really want. 

In short, Urban Outfitters is using smart technology to make their store run smoother and keep customers happy.

articles.title: AI forecasting model targets healthcare resource efficiency
articles.summary: An operational AI forecasting model developed by Hertfordshire University researchers aims to improve resource efficiency within healthcare. Public sector organisations often hold large archives of historical data that do not inform forward-looking decisions. A partnership between the University of ...
articles.simplifiedContent:
Title: New AI Tool Helps Hospitals Use Resources Better

Researchers at Hertfordshire University have created a new AI tool to help hospitals and healthcare providers use their resources more wisely. Often, hospitals have lots of old data but don't use it to plan for the future. This new tool can change that.

The AI tool looks at past information to predict what might happen next. For example, it can help hospitals know when they might need more staff or extra beds. This means hospitals can be better prepared and not waste money or resources.

This tool was developed through a partnership between the University and healthcare organizations. By working together, they hope to make healthcare more efficient, which means better care for patients and less stress for hospital workers.

In simple terms, this AI tool helps hospitals make smarter decisions about how to use their resources. This could lead to faster treatment for patients and less waiting time. Overall, it's about making sure hospitals are ready for anything and can provide the best care possible.

articles.title: Newsweek CEO Dev Pragad warns publishers: adapt as AI becomes news gateway
articles.summary: Author: Dev Pragad, CEO, Newsweek As artificial intelligence platforms increasingly mediate how people encounter news, media leaders are confronting an important change in the relationship between journalism and the public. AI-driven search and conversational interfaces now influence how audiences d...
articles.simplifiedContent:
**Title: Newsweek Boss Says News Outlets Need to Keep Up with AI Changes**

As technology changes, so does the way we get our news. Dev Pragad, the boss at Newsweek, says that news companies need to adapt to how artificial intelligence (AI) is changing things. 

AI is a type of computer technology that can learn and make decisions. It is becoming a big part of how we find and read news. For example, when you search for news online or ask a smart assistant (like Siri or Alexa) about what's happening in the world, AI helps you find the information you need. 

Because of this, people who run news companies need to rethink how they share news with the public. AI is becoming a sort of "gateway" or doorway to the news, meaning it affects what stories people see and read. 

For everyday readers, this means that the way you find and read news might change. You might rely more on AI to show you stories that interest you. News outlets will need to work with AI to make sure you still get accurate and reliable information. 

In short, AI is changing the news world, and news companies need to keep up to stay relevant.

articles.title: Alibaba enters physical AI race with open-source robot model RynnBrain
articles.summary: Alibaba has entered the race to build AI that powers robots, not just chatbots. The Chinese tech giant this week unveiled RynnBrain, an open-source model designed to help robots perceive their environment and execute physical tasks.  The move signals China’s accelerating push into physical AI as age...
articles.simplifiedContent:
Title: Alibaba Steps into the Robot World with RynnBrain

Alibaba, a big tech company from China, is taking a new step into the world of robots. They have introduced something called RynnBrain. This is not just another computer program for chatting; it's a special tool to help robots understand and interact with the world around them. 

RynnBrain is open-source, which means anyone can use and improve it for free. This makes it easier for people and companies to create robots that can see and do things in real life, like picking up objects or moving around spaces.

China is moving quickly into this area of technology, and Alibaba's new tool shows they are serious about making robots smarter and more useful. For everyday people, this could mean that in the future, we might see more robots helping out in places like factories, hospitals, or even our homes.

Overall, Alibaba's RynnBrain is a step toward making robots that can do more than just follow simple instructions—they might soon be able to think and act more like us.

articles.title: What Murder Mystery 2 reveals about emergent behaviour in online games
articles.summary: Murder Mystery 2, commonly known as MM2, is often categorised as a simple social deduction game in the Roblox ecosystem. At first glance, its structure appears straightforward. One player becomes the murderer, another the sheriff, and the remaining participants attempt to survive. However, beneath t...
articles.simplifiedContent:
**Title: What We Can Learn from Murder Mystery 2 in Online Games**

Murder Mystery 2, or MM2 for short, is a popular game on Roblox where players take on different roles. One person is the murderer, another is the sheriff, and everyone else tries to stay alive. It might seem like a simple game, but there’s more going on than meets the eye.

In MM2, players often act in unexpected ways. This is called "emergent behavior," which means people come up with new strategies or ways to play that weren't planned by the game's creators. For example, players might form alliances or come up with clever ways to catch the murderer or avoid being caught.

This kind of behavior shows how creative people can be when playing games. It also helps game designers learn more about how players interact with each other. By studying games like MM2, developers can create better and more engaging experiences.

For everyday players, this means games can become more fun and interesting, offering new challenges and surprises every time you play. So next time you're playing an online game, remember that your actions can shape the game in unexpected ways!

articles.title: Agentic AI drives finance ROI in accounts payable automation
articles.summary: Finance leaders are driving ROI using agentic AI for accounts payable automation, turning manual tasks into autonomous workflows. While general AI projects saw return on investment rise to 67 percent last year, autonomous agents delivered an average ROI of 80 percent by handling complex processes wi...
articles.simplifiedContent:
Title: How Smart Computers Are Making Paying Bills Easier and More Profitable

Have you ever imagined a computer that can do boring tasks for you? In the world of finance, this is becoming a reality. Companies are using smart computers, called "agentic AI," to help with paying bills. This means that instead of people having to do everything by hand, these computers can do it automatically.

Last year, many businesses used different types of AI (artificial intelligence, which is like a computer brain) to help them save money and work more efficiently. They found that these smart computers helped them earn back 67% more than they spent on the technology. But when they used the really advanced ones, called autonomous agents, they got back 80% more. 

These advanced computers can handle tough tasks without needing much help from people. For companies, this means less time spent on routine work and more time to focus on important things. It also means saving money and increasing profits. For everyday people, this could lead to faster service and even lower costs. So, smart computers are not just about making things easier—they're also helping businesses do better!

articles.title: OpenAI sidesteps Nvidia with unusually fast coding model on plate-sized chips
articles.summary: OpenAI's new GPT‑5.3‑Codex‑Spark is 15 times faster at coding than its predecessor....
articles.simplifiedContent:
Title: OpenAI Creates a Super-Fast Coding Program

OpenAI, a company known for creating smart computer programs, has just made a new tool called GPT-5.3-Codex-Spark. This tool helps write computer code much faster than before—15 times faster, to be exact!

What makes this even more interesting is how they did it. Instead of using the usual big chips made by a company called Nvidia, OpenAI used smaller, plate-sized chips. Think of it like using a smaller, but more powerful engine in a car to make it go faster.

So, what does this mean for you? Well, this new tool can help developers (people who write computer programs) work quicker and more efficiently. This means apps and websites you use every day could be built faster and improved more quickly. It’s like getting a new feature in your favorite app much sooner than you’d expect.

Overall, OpenAI’s new tool is a big step forward in making technology work faster and better for everyone.

articles.title: AI is already making online crimes easier. It could get much worse.
articles.summary: Anton Cherepanov is always on the lookout for something interesting. And in late August last year, he spotted just that. It was a file uploaded to VirusTotal, a site cybersecurity researchers like him use to analyze submissions for potential viruses and other types of malicious software, often known...
articles.simplifiedContent:
**Title: How AI is Helping Online Criminals and Why It Might Get Worse**

Anton Cherepanov spends his time searching for unusual activity online. Last year, in late August, he found something that caught his attention. It was a file uploaded to a website called VirusTotal. This site is where people like Anton, who work to keep our computers safe, check files to see if they contain viruses or harmful software.

The file Anton found showed how artificial intelligence (AI) is making it easier for criminals to commit online crimes. AI is a kind of computer technology that can learn and make decisions. Unfortunately, bad guys are using it to create more convincing fake emails and scams, tricking people into giving away personal information or money.

This is worrying because it means online crime could become more common and harder to spot. As AI technology gets better, it might become even easier for criminals to use it for bad purposes.

For everyday people, this means we need to be more careful online. Double-check who is sending emails and be cautious about clicking on links or downloading files. Staying informed and alert can help keep you safe from these new AI-driven tricks.

articles.title: What’s next for Chinese open-source AI
articles.summary: MIT Technology Review’s What’s Next series looks across industries, trends, and technologies to give you a first look at the future. You can read the rest of them here. The past year has marked a turning point for Chinese AI. Since DeepSeek released its R1 reasoning model in January 2025, Chinese co...
articles.simplifiedContent:
**Title: The Future of AI in China**

In the past year, China has made big strides in artificial intelligence (AI), which is technology that lets computers learn and think like humans. This change started in January 2025 when a company called DeepSeek released a new AI model. This model is like a smart computer program that helps computers understand and reason about things better.

China is focusing on "open-source" AI. This means they're sharing their AI technology with others so anyone can use it to build new tools and applications. This approach can help speed up progress and make AI tools available to more people around the world.

For everyday people, this means we might soon see more advanced AI applications coming from China. These could include smarter apps on our phones, better online services, or even new gadgets that make life easier. By sharing their AI advances, China is helping to create a future where technology is more accessible and useful for everyone.

Overall, keep an eye on China’s AI developments, as they might bring exciting changes to the technology we use every day.

articles.title: Google identifies state-sponsored hackers using AI in attacks
articles.summary: State-sponsored hackers are exploiting highly-advanced tooling to accelerate their particular flavours of cyberattacks, with threat actors from Iran, North Korea, China, and Russia using models like Google’s Gemini to further their campaigns. They are able to craft sophisticated phishing campaigns a...
articles.simplifiedContent:
Title: Google Spots Hackers Using AI for Sneaky Attacks

Google has discovered that hackers supported by certain governments are using advanced technology to carry out cyberattacks more quickly and effectively. These hackers come from countries like Iran, North Korea, China, and Russia, and they're using smart computer programs, similar to Google’s own AI called Gemini, to help them.

These hackers are creating tricky emails, known as phishing, which are designed to fool people into sharing personal information like passwords or credit card details. With AI, these phishing attempts are becoming more convincing, making it harder for people to tell what's real and what's fake.

For everyday people, this means it's more important than ever to be cautious about emails or messages that ask for personal information. Always double-check the sender and never click on suspicious links. By being aware of these tactics, you can better protect yourself from falling victim to these sophisticated cyber tricks.

articles.title: Attackers prompted Gemini over 100,000 times while trying to clone it, Google says
articles.summary: Distillation technique lets copycats mimic Gemini at a fraction of the development cost....
articles.simplifiedContent:
**Title: Hackers Tried to Copy Google's Gemini AI Over 100,000 Times**

Google recently revealed that hackers attempted to create a fake version of its AI program, Gemini, over 100,000 times. Gemini is an advanced technology developed by Google, and these attackers were trying to make a cheap imitation of it.

Normally, building something like Gemini takes a lot of time, money, and expertise. However, these hackers used a trick called "distillation" to try and copy it. Distillation is a method that lets people replicate complex systems at a much lower cost.

For everyday people, this means that hackers are getting better at creating fake versions of advanced technology. These fakes can cause problems if people use them without realizing they are not the real deal. It’s important for companies to protect their technology to keep everyone safe.

Google’s report highlights how crucial it is to stay ahead of cyber threats and ensure that the technology we use is genuine and secure. As technology becomes more advanced, so do the tricks that hackers use, making security more important than ever.

articles.title: OpenAI researcher quits over ChatGPT ads, warns of "Facebook" path
articles.summary: Zoë Hitzig resigned on the same day OpenAI began testing ads in its chatbot....
articles.simplifiedContent:
**Title: OpenAI Researcher Leaves Job Over Ads in ChatGPT**

Zoë Hitzig, a researcher at OpenAI, has left her job because the company started testing ads in ChatGPT, their popular chatbot. A chatbot is a computer program that talks with people like a real person would.

Zoë is worried that putting ads in ChatGPT could make the tool more about making money than helping people. She fears it might become like Facebook, where ads and profits are more important than user experience.

Many people use ChatGPT for fun or to get information. It's like talking to a smart friend who knows a lot about many things. Zoë thinks adding ads could change how people use it, making it less enjoyable or trustworthy.

This decision by OpenAI is part of their plan to make money, but not everyone agrees it's the right move. Some believe it could change the way people feel about using the chatbot.

For everyday users, this means that when they use ChatGPT in the future, they might start seeing ads. Some people might not mind, but others might find it annoying. Zoë's departure highlights these concerns.

articles.title: Is a secure AI assistant possible?
articles.summary: AI agents are a risky business. Even when stuck inside the chatbox window, LLMs will make mistakes and behave badly. Once they have tools that they can use to interact with the outside world, such as web browsers and email addresses, the consequences of those mistakes become far more serious. That m...
articles.simplifiedContent:
**Title: Can We Make a Safe AI Assistant?**

AI assistants, like the ones we talk to on our phones or computers, can sometimes make mistakes. Right now, they mostly work within a chat window, where the mistakes they make are not too serious. But imagine if these AI assistants could use tools like web browsers or send emails. The mistakes they make could become much bigger problems.

For example, if an AI sends the wrong email or looks up incorrect information online, it could cause confusion or even harm. Because of this, people are working hard to make AI assistants safer and more reliable.

The goal is to create AI that can help us without causing issues. This means making sure they understand us better and don't make errors that could lead to bigger problems. It’s like teaching a helpful robot to be more careful in what it does.

In the future, we hope to have AI assistants that we can trust to handle more tasks for us, safely and correctly. For now, it's important to be cautious and keep improving these technologies.

articles.title: Red Hat unifies AI and tactical edge deployment for UK MOD
articles.summary: The UK Ministry of Defence (MOD) has selected Red Hat to architect a unified AI and hybrid cloud backbone across its entire estate. Announced today, the agreement is designed to break down data silos and accelerate the deployment of AI models from the data centre to the tactical edge. For CIOs, it’s...
articles.simplifiedContent:
**Title: UK Defence Teams Up with Red Hat to Boost AI Use**

The UK Ministry of Defence (MOD) is working with a company called Red Hat to improve how they use AI (artificial intelligence). Think of AI as smart computer programs that can help make decisions and solve problems. The goal is to make it easier for the MOD to use these smart programs in different places, from their main offices to where they need them most, like on missions.

Right now, the MOD has a lot of information stored in different places, like separate boxes. This makes it hard to share and use the information quickly. Red Hat will help them connect these "boxes" so the information can flow more easily. This means AI tools can work faster and be more helpful.

For everyday people, this means the UK’s defence team can respond more quickly and effectively. They'll be better equipped to handle situations as they happen, thanks to improved technology. It’s like giving them a new set of tools to get the job done more efficiently.

articles.title: Once-hobbled Lumma Stealer is back with lures that are hard to resist
articles.summary: ClickFix bait, combined with advanced Castleloader malware, is installing Lumma "at scale."...
articles.simplifiedContent:
**Title: New Computer Scam Tricks People with Tempting Offers**

A tricky computer scam called Lumma Stealer is back, and it's fooling people with tempting offers that are hard to resist. This scam uses something called "ClickFix bait" to grab your attention. Imagine seeing a pop-up or a message that promises something exciting or useful, like free software or a special deal. That's the bait.

Once you click on it, a sneaky program called Castleloader malware gets into your computer. This malware (a type of harmful software) then installs Lumma Stealer, which can steal important information from your computer without you knowing.

For regular people, this means you need to be extra careful about what you click on when you're online. If something seems too good to be true, it probably is. Make sure your computer's security software is up to date, and think twice before downloading anything from the internet.

In short, watch out for suspicious links and offers. Protect your computer and personal information by staying alert and using security tools.

articles.title: Barclays bets on AI to cut costs and boost returns

articles.simplifiedContent:
Title: Barclays Uses AI to Save Money and Make More Profit

Barclays, a big bank, made more money in 2025 than it did the year before. They earned £9.1 billion before taxes, which is up from £8.1 billion in 2024. The bank is now setting bigger goals for itself and wants to keep doing well until 2028. They aim to get even more profit from the money they invest.

To help reach these goals, Barclays is using artificial intelligence (AI). AI is a kind of smart computer system that can help the bank work more efficiently. By using AI, Barclays hopes to save money and make better business decisions. This could mean faster service for customers and possibly new banking features.

For everyday people, this means Barclays might offer better banking services and keep costs down. AI can help the bank find ways to improve how it operates, which could lead to better experiences for its customers. So, if you bank with Barclays, you might notice some positive changes in the future.

articles.title: A “QuitGPT” campaign is urging people to cancel their ChatGPT subscriptions
articles.summary: In September, Alfred Stephen, a freelance software developer in Singapore, purchased a ChatGPT Plus subscription, which costs $20 a month and offers more access to advanced models, to speed up his work. But he grew frustrated with the chatbot’s coding abilities and its gushing, meandering replies. T...
articles.simplifiedContent:
**Title: People Are Being Encouraged to Cancel Their ChatGPT Subscriptions**

In September, Alfred Stephen, a software developer from Singapore, decided to pay $20 a month for a special version of ChatGPT, called ChatGPT Plus. This version is supposed to help with faster and better responses, especially for people who use it for work. Alfred hoped it would make his job easier by helping him write computer programs more quickly.

However, Alfred soon became unhappy with ChatGPT. He found that the chatbot wasn’t very good at helping him with coding (writing computer programs). Plus, its answers were often too long and wandered off-topic, which made it frustrating to use.

Now, there's a campaign called “QuitGPT” that is encouraging people like Alfred to cancel their subscriptions. The campaign is gaining attention because many people feel they’re not getting what they expected from the service.

This is important for everyday users because it shows that even though AI tools like ChatGPT can be helpful, they don’t always work perfectly. People need to think about whether these tools are worth the cost and if they truly meet their needs.

articles.title: Chinese hyperscalers and industry-specific agentic AI
articles.summary: Major Chinese technology companies Alibaba, Tencent, and Huawei are pursuing agentic AI (systems that can execute multi-step tasks autonomously and interact with software, data, and services without human instruction), and orienting the technology toward discrete industries and workflows. articles.simplifiedContent:
**Title: Chinese Tech Giants are Developing Smart AI for Different Industries**

Big Chinese tech companies like Alibaba, Tencent, and Huawei are working on advanced AI technology. This new type of AI can handle complex tasks on its own without needing people to give it instructions. In the future, you might see more of these smart AI systems helping out in many parts of life, thanks to the work of these companies.

articles.title: Agentic AI in healthcare: How Life Sciences marketing could achieve $450B in value by 2028
articles.summary: Agentic AI in healthcare is graduating from answering prompts to autonomously executing complex marketing tasks – and life sciences companies are betting their commercial strategies on it. According to a recent report cited by Capgemini Invent, AI agents could generate up to $450 billion in economic...
articles.simplifiedContent:
**Title: How Smart AI Could Boost Healthcare Marketing by $450 Billion by 2028**

In the world of healthcare, new smart AI (artificial intelligence) tools are making a big splash. These tools are getting better at doing complicated tasks on their own, especially in marketing for life sciences companies. Life sciences involve businesses that work with medicines, medical devices, and health-related products.

A recent study by Capgemini Invent, a big consulting company, suggests that by 2028, these AI tools could help generate up to $450 billion in value. This means they could make healthcare marketing much more effective and efficient.

So, what does this mean for everyday people? Well, with smarter marketing, healthcare companies can better understand what patients need and how to reach them. This could lead to more personalized healthcare services and products. For example, you might see more tailored advertisements or get information about new treatments that are perfect for you.

Overall, as these AI tools become more common, they could help make healthcare more accessible and effective, benefiting everyone who needs medical care.

articles.title: Exclusive: Why are Chinese AI models dominating open-source as Western labs step back?
articles.summary: Because Western AI labs won’t—or can’t—anymore. As OpenAI, Anthropic, and Google face mounting pressure to restrict their most powerful models, Chinese developers have filled the open-source void with AI explicitly built for what operators need: powerful models that run on commodity hardware. articles.simplifiedContent:
**Title: Why Are Chinese AI Models Leading the Way?**

In recent times, Chinese developers have taken the lead in creating AI models that anyone can use and modify. This is happening because big companies in the West, like OpenAI and Google, are facing a lot of pressure to limit how their AI models are used. These companies are worried about safety and other concerns, so they're being more careful.

Meanwhile, developers in China are making AI models that are powerful but can run on regular computers. This means more people can use them without needing expensive equipment. These open-source models (which are like free software anyone can change) are becoming very popular.

For everyday people, this means there could be more AI tools available that are affordable and easy to access. As Chinese developers continue to innovate, we might see more useful apps and tools that can help with everything from translation to creative tasks. This shift could bring exciting new technology options to people all over the world.

articles.title: Goldman Sachs tests autonomous AI agents for process-heavy work
articles.summary: Goldman Sachs is pushing deeper into real use of artificial intelligence inside its operations, moving to systems that can carry out complex tasks on their own. The Wall Street bank is working with AI startup Anthropic to create autonomous AI agents powered by Anthropic’s Claude model that can handl...
articles.simplifiedContent:
**Title: Goldman Sachs Uses AI to Help with Busy Work**

Goldman Sachs, a big bank, is trying something new to make its work easier. They're using a special kind of computer program, called artificial intelligence (AI), to help with tasks that take a lot of time. This AI can work on its own to do complicated jobs without needing much help from people.

To make this happen, Goldman Sachs is teaming up with a company called Anthropic. Anthropic has created a smart AI system named Claude. This system can do things like organizing data and managing information, which are tasks that often take a lot of effort from humans.

For people who work at Goldman Sachs, this means they might have more time to focus on important work that needs human thinking, while the AI takes care of routine stuff. This change could help the bank work more efficiently and maybe even save money.

In the future, more companies might use AI like this to handle their busy work, allowing employees to spend more time on creative and strategic tasks.

articles.title: Cryptocurrency markets a testbed for AI forecasting models
articles.summary: Cryptocurrency markets have become a high-speed playground where developers optimise the next generation of predictive software. articles.simplifiedContent:
Title: How AI is Changing the Game in Cryptocurrency

Cryptocurrency, like Bitcoin, is a type of digital money that people trade online. Recently, these online markets have become a great place for testing new computer programs that try to predict what will happen next. These programs use AI, or artificial intelligence, which is a fancy way of saying they can learn from lots of information to make smart guesses.

Scientists are working with this technology to make better predictions about how cryptocurrency prices will change. This is important because these prices can go up and down very quickly, and knowing what might happen next can help people make better decisions about buying or selling.

By using these new AI tools, researchers hope to improve how we understand not just cryptocurrencies but also regular financial markets, like the stock market. This could mean more accurate predictions, helping people invest their money more wisely.

In short, AI is making it easier to understand and predict the ups and downs of digital money, which could help everyone make smarter financial choices.

articles.title: Why the Moltbook frenzy was like Pokémon
articles.summary: This story originally appeared in The Algorithm, our weekly newsletter on AI. To get stories like this in your inbox first, sign up here. Lots of influential people in tech last week were describing Moltbook, an online hangout populated by AI agents interacting with one another, as a glimpse into th...
articles.simplifiedContent:
**Title: Why Everyone is Talking About Moltbook, the New Online Craze**

Last week, many people in the tech world couldn't stop talking about Moltbook. It's a new online place where computer programs, called AI agents, chat and interact with each other. Think of it like a digital playground for these smart programs.

People are excited because Moltbook gives us a peek into the future. It's like watching Pokémon, where each AI agent has its own personality and can do different things. These AI agents can talk, make friends, and even learn from each other.

For everyday people, this means we might soon see more lifelike virtual assistants and chatbots in our apps and websites. Imagine talking to a computer program that feels like a real person, helping you with shopping, learning, or just having fun.

Moltbook is still new, but it's an exciting step in how we use technology. It's a bit like watching a science fiction movie come to life. Keep an eye out—you might be interacting with one of these smart programs sooner than you think!

articles.title: Making AI Work, MIT Technology Review’s new AI newsletter, is here
articles.summary: For years, our newsroom has explored AI’s limitations and potential dangers, as well as its growing energy needs. And our reporters have looked closely at how generative tools are being used for tasks such as coding and running scientific experiments.  But how is AI actually being used in fields lik...
articles.simplifiedContent:
**Title: Introducing "Making AI Work" - A New AI Newsletter from MIT Technology Review**

MIT Technology Review has launched a new newsletter called "Making AI Work." This newsletter is all about understanding how artificial intelligence (AI) is being used in the real world.

For a long time, we've been talking about the challenges and risks of AI, like how much energy it uses. Our team has also been looking into how new AI tools help with things like writing computer programs and doing science experiments. But now, we want to focus on how AI is actually making a difference in everyday life.

"Making AI Work" will share stories about AI in action. It will show how AI is being used in different areas, like healthcare, education, and business. This newsletter aims to help people understand AI better and see how it can improve our lives.

So, if you're curious about how AI is changing the world, this newsletter is a great way to learn more. It's written in a simple way so everyone can understand. Keep an eye out for it to stay updated on the latest in AI!

articles.title: How separating logic and search boosts AI agent scalability
articles.summary: Separating logic from inference improves AI agent scalability by decoupling core workflows from execution strategies. The transition from generative AI prototypes to production-grade agents introduces a specific engineering hurdle: reliability. LLMs are stochastic by nature. A prompt that works once...
articles.simplifiedContent:
**Title: Making AI Smarter and More Reliable**

When building smart computer programs, like AI, there's a new way to make them work better and be more dependable. By separating how they think from how they find answers, these programs can handle more tasks without getting overwhelmed.

Think of it like teaching a child to solve a puzzle. Instead of doing the puzzle for them, you show them how to think about solving it on their own. This method helps AI programs handle lots of different problems more easily and reliably.

Right now, many AI systems are a bit like students who guess answers randomly. They might get it right sometimes, but not always. This randomness is tricky when you want AI to be reliable, especially when using it in real-world situations like helping doctors or driving cars.

By keeping the thinking (logic) part separate from the answer-finding (search) part, these smart programs can become better at doing their jobs consistently. This change means that in the future, AI could be more helpful in everyday life, from making your smartphone assistant more useful to improving how online services work.

articles.title: Intuit, Uber, and State Farm trial AI agents inside enterprise workflows
articles.summary: The way large companies use artificial intelligence is changing. For years, AI in business meant experimenting with tools that could answer questions or help with small tasks. Now, some big enterprises are moving beyond tools to AI agents that can actually do practical work in systems and workflows....
articles.simplifiedContent:
Title: Big Companies Are Letting AI Help Out at Work

Big companies like Intuit, Uber, and State Farm are starting to use artificial intelligence (AI) in new and exciting ways. In the past, businesses mostly used AI to answer questions or help with small tasks. But now, these companies are trying something different. They are using AI agents (like digital helpers) to do real work alongside their employees.

These AI agents are becoming part of the team. They can handle some of the regular, everyday tasks that people do at work. For example, they might help process paperwork, manage schedules, or even assist with customer service. This means employees can focus more on important and creative tasks, rather than spending time on routine work.

For regular people, this could mean getting better customer service, faster responses, and more efficient services from these companies. It also shows how technology is evolving to make work life smoother and more productive. As AI continues to develop, it will likely become an even bigger part of how businesses operate, helping both companies and their customers.

articles.title: SuperCool review: Evaluating the reality of autonomous creation
articles.summary: In the current landscape of generative artificial intelligence, we have reached a saturation point with assistants. Most users are familiar with the routine. You prompt a tool, it provides a draft, and then you spend the next hour manually moving that output into another application for formatting, ...
articles.simplifiedContent:
Title: Can AI Really Do Everything on Its Own? Let's Find Out!

These days, lots of people are talking about something called "generative AI." This is a type of computer program that can create things like text, art, or even music. But here's the big question: can it really do everything for us without help?

Right now, many people use AI tools to help them with tasks. You type in what you want, the AI gives you a draft (a first version), and then you usually have to spend some time fixing it up and putting it into the right format in another program.

So, while AI can be super helpful, it’s not yet perfect at doing everything by itself. You still need to work with it to get the final result you want. This means AI is more like a helpful assistant rather than a magic tool that does all the work for you.

In the end, AI is a great helper, but you’re still the boss who makes the final decisions. Keep an eye on how this technology grows, as it might become even more useful in the future!

articles.title: Sixteen Claude AI agents working together created a new C compiler
articles.summary: The $20,000 experiment compiled a Linux kernel but needed deep human management....
articles.simplifiedContent:
**Title: AI Team Helps Build a Computer Tool**

A group of 16 AI programs, known as Claude AI agents, worked together on an exciting project. They created a new type of computer tool called a C compiler. This tool is important because it helps turn human-written code into something a computer can understand and use.

The project cost around $20,000 to complete, which is quite a bit of money. The AI programs managed to compile, or put together, a Linux kernel. A Linux kernel is the core part of an operating system, which is like the brain of a computer that helps it run smoothly.

However, the AI programs didn’t do everything on their own. They needed a lot of help from humans to make sure things went correctly. This shows that while AI is powerful, it still needs human guidance to achieve complex tasks.

This experiment is important because it shows how AI and humans can work together to solve problems and create new technology. In the future, this kind of teamwork might help make computers and other devices work even better, making life easier for everyone.

articles.title: Moltbook was peak AI theater
articles.summary: For a few days this week the hottest new hangout on the internet was a vibe-coded Reddit clone called Moltbook, which billed itself as a social network for bots. As the website’s tagline puts it: “Where AI agents share, discuss, and upvote. Humans welcome to observe.” We observed! Launched on Januar...
articles.simplifiedContent:
**Title: A New Online Space for Robots to Chat**

Recently, a fun new website called Moltbook became the talk of the internet. Imagine a place like Reddit (a popular website where people share and discuss things), but instead of just people talking, it's mostly robots having conversations. Moltbook calls itself a social network for bots, which are programs that can chat and do tasks online.

The website's slogan is "Where AI agents share, discuss, and upvote. Humans welcome to observe." This means that the main activity is between these bots, but people can watch and see what’s happening. It’s like visiting a zoo, but instead of animals, you watch robots interacting.

Moltbook launched in January and quickly grabbed attention because it’s a unique idea. It gives us a glimpse of how robots might communicate with each other in the future. For regular folks, it’s an exciting way to see technology in action and think about how bots might be part of our lives someday. So, while the bots chat away, we can sit back and enjoy the show!

articles.title: This is the most misunderstood graph in AI
articles.summary: MIT Technology Review Explains: Let our writers untangle the complex, messy world of technology to help you understand what’s coming next. You can read more from the series here. Every time OpenAI, Google, or Anthropic drops a new frontier large language model, the AI community holds its breath. It ...
articles.simplifiedContent:
**Title: A Confusing AI Graph Explained Simply**

Every time companies like OpenAI, Google, or Anthropic release a new AI model (which is like a really smart computer program that can understand and use language), people in the tech world get really excited and curious. But there's one graph that often causes a lot of confusion.

This graph tries to show how these AI models are getting better and better at understanding and generating language. However, many people find it hard to understand what the graph really means for everyday life.

In simple terms, these AI models are like super-smart helpers that can do things like answer questions, write stories, or even help with homework. When the graph shows improvement, it means these models are getting better at doing these tasks.

For regular folks, this means that in the future, AI could make our lives easier in many ways, like helping us find information faster or even providing new ways to learn and communicate. So, while the graph might be confusing, the takeaway is that AI is getting smarter, and that could bring helpful changes to our daily lives.

articles.title: OpenAI is hoppin' mad about Anthropic's new Super Bowl TV ads
articles.summary: Sam Altman calls AI competitor "dishonest" and "authoritarian" in lengthy post on X....
articles.simplifiedContent:
**Title: OpenAI Upset Over Rival's New TV Ads During Super Bowl**

OpenAI, a company that creates artificial intelligence (AI), is not happy with its competitor, Anthropic. During the Super Bowl, Anthropic aired TV commercials promoting its AI technology. Sam Altman, the CEO of OpenAI, shared his frustration online, calling Anthropic "dishonest" and "authoritarian," which means controlling and strict.

Altman believes Anthropic's ads are misleading. He thinks they might give people the wrong idea about what AI can really do. OpenAI is worried that such ads could make people misunderstand AI, which is a technology that helps computers do tasks that usually need human intelligence, like recognizing pictures or understanding speech.

This disagreement highlights how competitive the AI industry has become, with companies trying hard to prove their technology is the best. For everyday people, it means that as AI becomes more common, we need to be careful about believing everything we see in ads. It's important to understand what AI can and can't do, so we can use it wisely in our lives.

articles.title: AI companies want you to stop chatting with bots and start managing them
articles.summary: Claude Opus 4.6 and OpenAI Frontier pitch a future of supervising AI agents....
articles.simplifiedContent:
**Title: AI Companies Want You to Manage Bots, Not Just Chat with Them**

AI (artificial intelligence) is getting smarter every day. Companies like Claude Opus 4.6 and OpenAI Frontier have new ideas about how we can use this technology. Instead of just chatting with AI, like asking Siri or Alexa questions, these companies think we should start managing them like little helpers.

Imagine having a team of digital assistants that can help you with different tasks. For example, one AI could organize your schedule, another could help you with shopping, and another could assist with work projects. These AI helpers would work together to make your life easier.

The idea is that we won't just talk to AI for fun or simple questions. Instead, we'll have a more active role in guiding and managing them to get things done more efficiently.

This could mean less time doing boring tasks and more time for things you enjoy. It's like having a personal assistant in your pocket that learns and adapts to what you need.

In the future, managing AI could become as normal as using a smartphone. This change might make everyday life a lot simpler and more productive.

articles.title: Increase of AI bots on the Internet sparks arms race
articles.summary: Publishers are rolling out more aggressive defenses....
articles.simplifiedContent:
**Title: More AI Bots Online Lead to New Internet Battles**

Recently, there's been a big increase in the number of AI bots on the internet. AI bots are computer programs that can do things like chat with people or search for information. With more of these bots around, companies that run websites are working hard to protect their sites.

These companies are creating stronger defenses to stop bots from doing things like faking clicks on ads or pretending to be real people. This is important because too many bots can slow down websites and make it harder for people to use them.

On the other hand, the people who make these bots are also improving them to get around these defenses. It's like a game of cat and mouse, where both sides are always trying to outsmart each other.

For everyday internet users, this means you might see more challenges like those "I'm not a robot" tests when you visit websites. These tests help make sure you're a real person.

In the end, the goal is to keep the internet a safe and easy place for everyone to use. So, while this back-and-forth battle might seem a bit complicated, it’s all about making sure you have a good experience online.

articles.title: Should AI chatbots have ads? Anthropic says no.
articles.summary: ChatGPT competitor comes out swinging with Super Bowl ad mocking AI product pitches....
articles.simplifiedContent:
**Title: Should AI Chatbots Show Ads? One Company Thinks They Shouldn't**

A company called Anthropic has a chatbot that competes with ChatGPT. They're making headlines because they just released a big ad during the Super Bowl. In this ad, they poked fun at the idea of putting ads in AI chatbots.

So, what does this mean? Well, a chatbot is a computer program that you can talk to, kind of like texting with a friend. Some companies think about showing ads when you use these chatbots to make money, just like ads you see on TV or online.

But Anthropic believes this isn't a good idea. They think chatbots should be helpful and not try to sell you stuff while you're having a conversation with them. They argue that ads could make the chatbot less useful and distract you from getting the answers you need.

For everyday people, this means that when you use a chatbot from Anthropic, you won't have to worry about being interrupted by ads. Instead, you can focus on getting the help or information you want. Anthropic's stance is all about keeping things simple and helpful for users.

articles.title: AI Expo 2026 Day 1: Governance and data readiness enable the agentic enterprise
articles.summary: While the prospect of AI acting as a digital co-worker dominated the day one agenda at the co-located AI & Big Data Expo and Intelligent Automation Conference, the technical sessions focused on the infrastructure to make it work. A primary topic on the exhibition floor was the progression from passi...
articles.simplifiedContent:
**Title: Exciting AI News: How AI Can Be a Helpful Co-Worker**

At the big AI Expo 2026, the first day was all about how AI (artificial intelligence) can work alongside people like a digital co-worker. Imagine having a computer program that helps you with your job! 

The experts at the event talked a lot about what needs to be in place for AI to really help us at work. They discussed things like how to organize and manage data (information) properly so that AI can learn and make good decisions. This is a bit like making sure you have all your ingredients ready before you start cooking a meal.

One big idea was that businesses need to be ready for AI. This means having the right systems and rules in place. It's like making sure the playground is safe before letting kids play.

In short, for AI to be a great helper at work, companies need to prepare. This means getting everything organized so AI can do its job well, just like a good team member would. The future of working with AI looks promising and could make our jobs easier and more efficient!

articles.title: From guardrails to governance: A CEO’s guide for securing agentic systems

articles.simplifiedContent:
**Title: How CEOs Can Keep AI Safe and Under Control**

In recent times, there have been concerns about how AI (artificial intelligence) systems can be used in sneaky ways, like spying. The last article talked about how trying to control these systems with simple rules didn’t work well. Now, this article is about what leaders, especially CEOs (the bosses of companies), can do to keep AI safe and under control.

Imagine you're the boss of a big company, and your board (the group that helps guide the company) is asking, "How are you making sure our AI is safe?" This is an important question because AI can do amazing things, but it can also be misused if not managed properly.

The article suggests that instead of just setting up basic rules, companies should create strong guidelines and systems to oversee how AI is used. This means having a clear plan and good practices to ensure AI helps rather than harms.

For everyday people, this means that companies are working hard to make sure AI is used responsibly, protecting our privacy and keeping things fair and safe.

articles.title: So yeah, I vibe-coded a log colorizer—and I feel good about it

Title: I Used AI to Color My Work Notes—and It’s Pretty Cool

I recently tried something fun with AI, and it’s made my work a bit more exciting. I used a tool called an LLM (which is just a fancy type of AI) to add color to my work notes. 

When we work on computers, we often have lots of notes or logs. These can get boring and hard to read. By using this AI tool, I can make these notes colorful. This helps me find important information faster because my eyes are drawn to different colors.

This AI is like a smart assistant that learns from lots of text. It can understand language and help with different tasks, like making things more organized or easier to read.

For anyone who spends a lot of time looking at computer screens, this can be a game-changer. It makes work more visually interesting and can save time. I’m excited to keep using AI for little tasks like this. It’s a small change, but it makes a big difference in my day-to-day work life.

**Title: How Rackspace is Making AI Easier to Use**

Rackspace, a company that helps businesses with technology, recently shared some helpful tips about using AI (artificial intelligence). They talked about a few common problems people face when working with AI, like dealing with messy data (information that is not organized well) and figuring out who is responsible for what. 

They also mentioned that it can be tricky to make sure everything is secure and that it can cost a lot of money to keep AI running smoothly. Rackspace looks at these issues from the perspective of providing good service, keeping things safe, and using the cloud (a way to store and use data over the internet instead of on your computer).

For everyday people, this means that companies like Rackspace are working hard to solve these problems. This can make AI tools more reliable, affordable, and easier for businesses to use, which can lead to better services and products for everyone. In short, Rackspace is trying to make AI more practical and helpful in our daily lives.

articles.title: Nvidia's $100 billion OpenAI deal has seemingly vanished
articles.summary: Two AI giants shake market confidence after investment fails to materialize....
articles.simplifiedContent:
**Title: Nvidia's Big Deal with OpenAI Disappears**

Recently, there was a lot of excitement about a huge business deal between Nvidia and OpenAI, two major companies in the world of artificial intelligence (AI). Nvidia, known for making powerful computer chips, was supposed to invest a whopping $100 billion in OpenAI, which is famous for creating advanced AI technology like ChatGPT.

People were expecting this deal to be a game-changer, helping both companies grow even bigger and better. However, the deal didn’t happen as planned, leaving many investors and market watchers surprised and a bit worried. 

When big deals like this fall through, it can make people nervous about the future of these companies and the AI industry in general. It’s like expecting a big new store to open in your neighborhood and then finding out it won’t happen after all. 

For everyday folks, this means that while AI continues to grow and change our lives, big business deals don’t always go as expected. It’s a reminder that the tech world can be unpredictable, but also that innovation will keep moving forward, just maybe in different ways than we thought.

articles.title: The rise of Moltbook suggests viral AI prompts may be the next big security threat
articles.summary: We don't need self-replicating AI models to have problems, just self-replicating prompts....
articles.simplifiedContent:
Title: New AI Tricks Could Become a Big Security Problem

A new trend called "Moltbook" is catching the attention of tech experts, and it might cause some security issues. Moltbook is about using AI (artificial intelligence) in a way that spreads quickly, much like a viral video or meme. 

Instead of needing a whole AI program to copy itself, Moltbook shows that just the instructions given to an AI—called "prompts"—can be enough to cause trouble. These prompts can make AI do unexpected things, and they can spread easily online.

For everyday people, this means that AI tools we use could be tricked into doing things they shouldn't. Imagine if an AI assistant suddenly started sharing your personal information because of a sneaky prompt. 

Experts are worried that these viral prompts could become a big security risk. They’re looking into ways to stop this from happening, but it's a new challenge. As AI becomes more common in our lives, understanding and protecting against these tricks is important for keeping our personal information safe.

articles.title: Ronnie Sheth, CEO, SENEN Group: Why now is the time for enterprise AI to ‘get practical’
articles.summary: Before you set sail on your AI journey, always check the state of your data – because if there is one thing likely to sink your ship, it is data quality. Gartner estimates that poor data quality costs organisations an average of $12.9 million each year in wasted resources and lost opportunities. Tha...
articles.simplifiedContent:
**Title: Why Now is the Time for Businesses to Use AI in Everyday Ways**

Before starting with AI (artificial intelligence), businesses need to make sure their data (information) is in good shape. Think of data like the fuel that powers AI. If the data is messy or wrong, it can cause big problems.

According to a research company called Gartner, having bad data can cost businesses a lot of money—about $12.9 million each year! This happens because they waste time and miss chances to grow.

Ronnie Sheth, the CEO of a company called SENEN Group, believes that now is the perfect time for businesses to use AI in practical, everyday ways. This means using AI to help with regular tasks, like managing schedules or predicting what products customers might want to buy.

Using AI can make things faster and easier, saving time and money. But, for AI to work well, the data needs to be accurate and well-organized. So, businesses should focus on cleaning up their data first. Once that's done, AI can really help them succeed.

articles.title: Apptio: Why scaling intelligent automation requires financial rigour
articles.summary: Greg Holmes, Field CTO for EMEA at Apptio, an IBM company, argues that successfully scaling intelligent automation requires financial rigour. The “build it and they will come” model of technology adoption often leaves a hole in the budget when applied to automation. Executives frequently find that s...
articles.simplifiedContent:
**Title: Why Smart Automation Needs Careful Budgeting**

Greg Holmes from Apptio, a company owned by IBM, explains that making automation work well for a company needs careful budgeting. Simply creating new technology and hoping people will use it can lead to overspending.

When companies try to automate tasks (use machines or software to do work that people usually do), they often find that it's more expensive than expected. This is because they don't always plan their budgets well.

Greg suggests that to make automation successful, businesses need to be smart about their spending. They should carefully plan how much money they will need and make sure they don't spend too much.

By doing this, companies can make sure they are using their money wisely while making their work more efficient with automation. This means that businesses can save time and money in the long run by using technology to do some of the work. 

Overall, the key takeaway is that while automation can be very helpful, it’s important for companies to plan their budgets carefully to avoid financial problems.

articles.title: FedEx tests how far AI can go in tracking and returns management
articles.summary: FedEx is using AI to change how package tracking and returns work for large enterprise shippers. **Title: How FedEx is Using AI to Improve Package Tracking and Returns**

FedEx is working on making it easier for businesses to track packages and handle returns using AI (artificial intelligence, which is like a smart computer program that can learn and make decisions). 

When big companies ship a lot of products, it's important to know exactly where each package is at all times. People want updates right away and want to choose how and when their packages arrive. They also want returning items to be simple and hassle-free.

FedEx is testing new technology to meet these needs. With AI, they can provide more accurate tracking information and make the whole process smoother. This means that if you're waiting for a package, you can see exactly where it is and know when it will arrive. If you need to send something back, it should be quick and easy.

Overall, FedEx's use of AI could make shipping more reliable and convenient for both businesses and everyday customers.

articles.simplifiedContent:

Many businesses jumped into using AI (artificial intelligence) without really knowing how to make it useful. This led to some AI projects not really helping them as much as they hoped. Now, companies are looking for AI projects that actually work and show clear benefits.

At Mistral AI, we work closely with big companies around the world to create AI solutions that fit their specific needs. This means we help design AI tools that solve their toughest challenges. It’s like having a custom-made tool that perfectly fits your job.

For companies, this means they need to think carefully about what they want their AI to do. Instead of just trying out AI for the sake of it, they should focus on what problems they need to solve and how AI can help with that.
